sn42.1:4.2: Then the chief Fury went up to the Buddha,
sn42.1:4.3: bowed, sat down to one side,
sn42.1:4.5: “What is the cause, sir, what is the reason why some people are regarded as furious,
sn42.1:4.6: while others are regarded as sweet-natured?”
sn42.1:4.7: “Take someone who hasn’t given up greed.
sn42.1:4.8: So they get irritated by others, and they show it.
sn42.1:4.11: So they get irritated by others, and they show it.
sn42.1:4.14: So they get irritated by others, and they show it.
sn42.1:4.16: This is the cause, this is the reason why some people are regarded as furious.
sn42.1:5.1: But take someone who has given up greed.
sn42.1:5.2: So they don’t get irritated by others, and don’t show it.
sn42.1:5.5: So they don’t get irritated by others, and don’t show it.
sn42.1:5.8: So they don’t get irritated by others, and don’t show it.
sn42.1:5.10: This is the cause, this is the reason why some people are regarded as sweet-natured.
sn42.1:6.1: When he said this, the chief Fury said to the Buddha:
sn42.1:6.3: As if he was righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark
sn42.1:6.4: so people with good eyes can see what’s there,
sn42.1:6.5: so too the Buddha has made the teaching clear in many ways.
sn42.1:6.6: I go for refuge to the Buddha, to the Dharma, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.
sn42.1:6.7: From this day forth, may the Buddha remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”
